# Question 1

a)  Using JSON YouTube: YouTube uses JSON to deliver video metadata, comments, and user interactions through its API. The JSON structure is hierarchical and includes nested fields for video IDs, thumbnails, and statistics such as views and likes. YouTubeâ€™s backend likely uses BigQuery and other Google Cloud services to store and manage data. The API fetches this data in JSON format, commonly consumed by frontend JavaScript frameworks.

b)  Using XML W3Schools: W3Schools offers XML data examples, including a sample file that provides information on books. The XML structure uses descriptive tags such as <book>, <author>, and <price>. The data can be accessed using XML parsers in JavaScript or server-side languages. Technologies like DOM and XSLT are used to query or transform the XML structure for web display.

# Question 2

i)  

``` sql
SELECT student.ID
FROM student
LEFT JOIN advisor ON student.ID = advisor.s_ID
WHERE advisor.i_ID IS NULL;
```

ii) 

``` sql
SELECT I.ID, I.name
FROM instructor I
WHERE NOT EXISTS (
  SELECT *
  FROM course C
  WHERE C.dept_name = I.dept_name
    AND NOT EXISTS (
      SELECT *
      FROM teaches T
      WHERE T.ID = I.ID AND T.course_id = C.course_id
    )
)
ORDER BY I.name;
```
